title: Cornell Gameday
text:
Cornell Gameday The Ithaca Journal 5:21 p.m. EDT October 9, 2015 Coming off of its third single-digit loss of the season, the Cornell football team faces its toughest test to date when Harvard, the defending Ivy champion, invades Schoellkopf Field for a noon start. Big Red bear. 
Who: No. 24 Harvard Crimson (3-0 overall, 1-0 Ivy League) at Cornell Big Red (0-3, 0-1) 
When: Noon 
Where: Schoellkopf Field (25,597), Ithaca 
Radio: WHCU (870) 
Live stats: cornellbigred.com 
Live video: IvyLeagueDigitalNetwork.com (subscription required) 
Series: Harvard leads, 45-32-2, and has won the last nine meetings, including last season's 24-7 victory in Cambridge, Mass. Cornell's most recent victory, 27-13, came on Oct. 8, 2005. 
Last meeting: On Oct. 11, 2014, the Big Red traded blows with the defending champion Crimson for 30 minutes, and the teams went into the halftime locker room tied at 0. But Harvard scored 17 straight points over 13 1/2 minutes of the second half and prevailed, 24-7. Cornell's defense yielded just 71 yards in the first half while forcing three Harvard turnovers. Jake Jatis hit Collin Shaw for a 26-yard touchdown with 3:18 to play for the Red's lone score. 
Coaches: For Harvard, Tim Murphy, Springfield '78 (22nd season, 150-62). For Cornell, David Archer, Cornell â€™05 (third season, 4-19 overall, 3-13 Ivy League). 
Leaders: For Harvard, sr. QB Scott Hosch (49-for-77, 708 yards, 6 TDs, 1 INT); sr. RB Paul Stanton Jr. (46-274, 4 TDs); sr. WR Andrew Fischer (12-126); sr. LB Jacob Lindsey (20 tackles). For Cornell, jr. QB Robert Somborn (47-for-79, 662 yards, 5 TD, 2 INTs); sr. RB Luke Hagy (52-343, 4 TDs; 9-73 receiving); so. WR James Hubbard (8-138, 2 TDs); so. S Nick Gesualdi (26 tackles); sr OLB J.J. Fives (18 tackles, 1 sack); jr. ILB Jackson Weber (17 tackles, 2 sacks); jr. P Chris Fraser (12-45.4). 
Quick facts: The Harvard offensive line has yet to allow a sack of quarterback Scott Hosch this season. ... The Crimson has won 12 consecutive Ivy League games since the end of the 2013 season, tying a program record set in 2002. ... Cornell's Hagy and Harvard's Stanton are the top two rushers in the Ivies thus far. ... The Crimson, which routed Georgetown 45-0 last week, is scoring 46.7 points per game and totaling 468 yards of offense per game. 
Next game: Cornell makes it second trip to Connecticut next weekend when it takes on Sacred Heart in Fairfield, in its final non-conference game of the season.
